Apparently 107 pixels per inch is enough to bring a device from high definition into extreme high definition.Whatever the numbers really mean doesn't mean a whole lot to most people. This screen is dazzling and it will not disappoint you.StorageA 16 gig HDD isn't too terrible for something that costs $229. The main issue here is that if you intend to use the feature allowing you to store 1080p movies then those 16 gigabytes will fill up rather quickly. It is also apparent that the operating system and support software will also take up a portion of that 16 gigabytes. As with nearly all devices of this type one can assume that it is likely that you will never be able to increase the size of this hard drive.Form FactorKindle Fires have always been build like a tank. They were able to take a beating and are more difficult to crack than other screen-based items. Unfortunately, this comes with the price that the Kindle Fire was rather bulky and clunky. This time around we get a nice slim device that also seems durable. It is comfortable to hold in your hand without feeling cheap. The width went from 0.9 inches to 0.6 inches (33% thinner!) and the weight went from .86 pounds to .66 pounds.New Operating systemRecently, the Kindle Fire operating system has started to become a bit more difficult to use. Things seems to be a little bit less user friendly, though it did have a lot more features. I got to see an older generation in my family struggle when the OS got an upgrade for the Kindle Fire HD.The New Operating System is called Mojito and it is based on androids JellyBean. This feels more iterative than a revamp but some things about it definitely work. You still have the carousel with Mojito, but you can view more apps at once which definitely makes this feature more usable. Silk now feels like something I might actually want to use. I feel that this has has the biggest upgrade with the new operating system. The Keyboard here feels much smoother and pages definitely seem to have loaded faster (though i guess i should thank the increased specs for that one). This is also helped along by the fact that the touch screen is far more accurate. I can't be certain of who to thank but this is definitely a smoother, more pleasurable experience.New FeaturesAs we know there are many things to like about amazons Kindle. People can go back and forth comparing the size, quality, and price of this item to that of an iPad. Here are a few argument winners that will help to sway people into the Amazon ecosystem.Prime Viewing...now watch Prime without internetYou will now be able to download amazon prime content directly to the hard drive of your Kindle. This means you can enjoy a long car trip or a plane ride without using 3G service. This is a great upgrade and truly has this item stand apart.X-RAY just got better (sorta)Now with X-RAY you can bring up imdb.com information on people that have just come into the screen. This is partly and old feature but it will become new again with trivia. This is just the trivia that is already provided on the imdb.com website, but it is a fun addition. There are also instances where you can follow certain lyrics line by line. At the time of the review I have yet to try out this feature.The idea of adding more to X-RAY is nice. Anything that makes watching a movie more immerse is a good thing. Unfortunately, this kinda feels like something that you will forget about very quickly. Though, there is a push for this kind of content nowadays (SmartGlass) so maybe it could become something we all naturally all use, time will tell i supposeMaydayTo me, this is the thing that really drew my attention.  This is definitely something that is meant to be used by my parents but it gives a warm to the product. A savy electronics user may never need to use Mayday in order to find out where the home button is but it would be fantastic if this type of feature is forever integrated into devices by other companies. Hopefully, this free service will be a game-changer for customer service.Why Only Four Stars? (small drawbacks)The new Kindle Fire HDX is a fantastic piece of hardware. It is light, beautiful, and fast. Unfortunately, this device feels as locked down as previous Kindle Fire models.The the entire Kindle Fire line boasts that it is compatible with 80,000 apps. This number looks really high but there are nearly 10x as many apps on the android store that are not compatible with the Kindle Fire. Kindle items are Android devices of sorts, why can't they run every app available?In addition to this there still does not seem to be any way to create your own home screen wallpaper. I have seen with previous devices that even with the ads turned off you still cannot choose your own home screen. The images they have provided are stunning, yet there is no customization. There should at least be a way to set your home screen to reflect the image of the book you have most recently read.Holding the device is wonderful, it is light and the face of the device is beautiful. The back has a rubber touch to it and the side has a nice angle to it. The power button and the volume rocker are on this angled surface which is nice, but it's not entirely impossible to feel a bit uncomfortable at first. One thing that is curious to me is that the speakers have been moved to the back. They have a nicer speaker set this time around but it seems unusual to me to be projecting that backward. In addition to this is seems possible to me that some people might naturally want to hold the device with their fingers covering these speaker holes. Clearly, these are minor issues that may not amount to much once you get accustomed to it.If you have come to this page looking for a way to figure out if you should get the 7" or the 8.9" I have one insight for you. I have never held the 8.9" but one instant difference is that the larger device has a rear facing camera. This wouldn't be a deal-breaker for me but i thought it might be important to note this.These few issues are very petty and, in the long run, they are insignificant. I am just shocked that such a fantastic device has such unusual restrictions. I cannot imagine that this would ruin the device for any buyer, but I felt it would only be fair to make you aware.This device is beautiful and deserves a spot in your home if you are looking for an upgrade. I love the look and feel of this device, I will just be sitting here hoping that the next time around we get a stock android device, though maybe I should just be happy that this thing will keep a huge smile on my face for a very long time.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HDX 7" 64GB and Prime downloads "SPOILER"
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Usagi Driver"
Reviews.Content: The HDX is magnificent, just read all the raves. Being a Prime member since 2005, I am totally Amazon oriented...music, books, movies.  The Fire is the perfect tablet for me.  Don't even care about the rest. Comparing brands and models are moot. I've owned all three generations and look forward to next years. I know I'll get one.  (I read on a Paperwhite. Only way to read in my opinion.)Anyway, now the beef. Prime downloading!  Amazon is the ONLY service allowing the DOWNLOADING of none owned content. Amazing! Give me 64GB (53.7GB available to user). Ahhh, now the TRUTH...ONLY TWO MOVIES OR EPISODE at a time. If Amazon had come out and said that...been honest...I wouldn't need 64GB.I know, I'm 65, been around the block a few times. Been fooled even more. The marketing guys got me again.  I just wish Amazon would tell the real truth once in a while.  Like the Lending Library.  One book a month, twelve books a year. I appreciate the 12 free reads but it would have been nice to know the TRUTH in the ad. It just irks me.I love my wife and I love Amazon.  (My wife a lot more, naturally.)  They both keep the truth from me at times.  At least I can get back at my wife!Amazon is striving to be the most customer oriented company and is pretty close to making it.  But their marketing people need a spanking!

Reviews.Title: I owned a Nook for 18 months....
Reviews.Author: Fetty99
Reviews.Content: I got tired of the lame Nook apps, and the lack of quality in the Nook.  It was also frustrating seeing that they are about to go under on the tablet front.  That led me to review the Kindle.  I purchased it over a week ago and have to say it was the best electronics purchase I've made in my 49 years.  This thing is the most amazing tablet ever.  I not only gave the Nook to my mom, who only plays solotaire on it, but I gave my 2 year old iPad to my nephew and will purchase the 9 inch HDX soon.  The 7 inch is faster and simply nicer than my iPad.  I hope Kindle comes out with a smartphone soon so I can boot Apple out all together.  Thanks Amazon for making the best reader/tablet on the market!  So happy!

Reviews.Title: PURPLE SCREEN FRINGE
Reviews.Author: J. Wilson
Reviews.Content: If Amazon can fix the issue of the purple haze around the edge of my screen, as well as that of many of the other reviewers, I think they will have a great tablet in the HDX. As it is now this tablet is unacceptable. It is going back.Edit:I just received the following in an email from Amazon after they read my review. This was not from me contacting them:"I've read your recent review on the Kindle Fire HDX, and I'm sorry for the trouble.Displays vary, and when using your device, you may see some light along the edge of the display. The accurate and rich colors of the Kindle Fire HDX display are created using a display backlight that is tinted slightly blue/purple. If the light you see along the edge of the display appears blue/purple, this is normal."

Reviews.Title: Ready to throw it against the wall!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: My kindle hdx keeps disconnecting from wifi.  I've looked through everything I could find online to fix the problem, but nothing works!  I talked to a cs rep last week.  He was very nice.  However, it took a lot of pressing from me to get him to admit this is a common, ongoing problem.  He took down my name and number and promised to call me in two days.  No call so far.  My laptop, regular kindle hd and my first generation kindle have no problem with wifi.  Ok, I think I might be done venting, but still very frustrated.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet for the right demographic
Reviews.Author: Deedubau
Reviews.Content: I had this tablet and cover for about a week and I think it's a great device. The design, the weight, the very easy and straightforward UI, and the reading experience. When you pick up the device for the first time  it feels really solid and not too heavy like the Kindle fire HD did. The software and user interface is really smooth and doesn't stutter. Unlike android tablets I didn't feel overwhelmed at all and it's just extremely easy to grasp and navigate. Without the official cover, I found the back buttons confusing to use, and even then it wasn't much better because it was annoying to reach behind the flap and press on the button I needed every time. Here are my other thoughts on this device:ReadingThe reading experience is really great, but just keep in mind that the borders of the screen have a light blue hue to it, which is apparently normal and didn't annoy me. Super crisp text, different fonts, different highlighted colors and the text to speech voice along with buying audiobooks to read along is great. As a matter of fact, I put the device to sleep and had it read me a number of books a few times. The text to speech feels really natural and I would imagine this being a selling point for some since the e-ink readers no longer provide this feature. The only issue I have right now is that it doesn't provide collections like the iOS app does, but from what I understand it's coming in a future update.Video/audioThe videos look and sound fantastic, and the stereo speakers are good enough to the point where I don't even need to use my Jambox blueooth speaker like I did for my iPads. Netflix, Amazon Prime videos, Hulu and even the CW app (I'm addicted to this show called the The Tomorrow People) are all there. Now, if you're a youtube fan DO NOT expect a good experience for this because it's currently only done on the mobile web. The pictures on the Kindle Fire HDX page show an integrated app, so that's either incorrect or I'm guessing it's not complete yet. The mobile web is not a great experience because you can't easily view your favorites and it's just not as good as using a native app. And sideloading (which I'll talk more about later) the app doesn't let you log into youtube because the logon needs to work with a unmodified Android UI device.Web BrowsingIt's very fast and smooth, but i t only lets you have about 5 tabs at once. This is the first Amazon Silk browser that's given me a good experience to the point where I didn't think I needed to sideload a faster browser. I like how you can default it to pick to load either a full webpage or mobile site. This is great for casual browsing but I'm a big tab and web surfer so I really would've preferred using chrome and all my saved bookmarks there.AppsIf you don't have any specific app you need in mind then the selection is pretty good. It has a lot of the major ones out there but some of the ones missing in the amazon app store like dropbox and instagram aren't there. You can however sideload them :) The games run super smooth on this device thanks to the state of the art Snapdragon 800 processor but don't expect any big android game launches to appear on this device right away. The last big one is Dead Trigger 2 which still hasn't appeared in the amazon app store yet.Battery lifeLike my previous generation Kindle Fires, not good at all in my experience. It charges a lot faster than the older generations, but I average about maybe 5ish hours for this device, and that's with either no or occasional video. I never had this issue with my iPads, but I always feel like I'm charging the Kindle Fires more than I'm using them.Final thoughts and opinionsNotice how I mentioned sideload a few times in this review. I honestly think if you want to take full advantage of what the tablet offers (and tinker around with it), then this might not be for you. It's designed (and designed to make money off of) for people who only stick to the amazon ecosystem and do a fair amount of reading. As much as I enjoyed using the device, I realized that the Nexus  7 would be a better fit for my needs. I can do without the text to speech and settle for a 3rd rate Kindle reading experience (it's much better on iOS) where I can't change the text, do X-ray or view popular highlights. I do have a Paperwhite so I'm fine without having this on my tablet. I guess the more I used my HDX, the less I was interesting in reading because it was able to do so much more than that. I returned my HDX today for the Nexus 7 and even though it's a bit more underpowered, I'm happy with owning an Android tablet that gives me full access to android apps via the play store. For everyone else, this is a great purchase anyone who doesn't mind the amazon ecosystem and loves shopping on amazon while taking advantage of their prime membership. Free videos and books to borrow every month! Ok it's not free but it sounds better saying it that way.

Reviews.Title: Traded in My 8.9 Kindle Fire for Kindle Fire HDX
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Colton Books"
Reviews.Content: First of all, I am a female (58) electronics junkie. I stopped spending money on house decorations and frivolous stuff to feed my habit. I did sell my 8.9 Kindle Fire to Amazon to trade in for this newer model HDX 7. My husband uses my older Kindle Fire HD now. I have the iPad 10" and could not see having two larger screen tablets. I needed a 7" device for more mobility and plan to use the Kindle Fire HDX 7 to carry with me. As a prime member, and invested in Amazon cloud space, books, videos, music, and apps, The Kindle Fire HDX was a smarter purchase than the Google Nexus.Not sorry that I made the trade. The video play is fantastic and the games are easy to see and very clear. The device is a lot faster responding, especially online. My uses for the device include: watching videos, playing mindless games, checking emails, browsing online, and writing notes for manuscript. I have a Kindle Paperwhite for reading and use it more than I would the Kindle Fire HDX, except for some "how to books" or magazines. I did notice a thin smidgeon of purple, but it did not distract me. There are too many major pluses in this device to send it back for that one tiny annoyance (however, it doesn't bother me at all).

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HDX
Reviews.Author: azog
Reviews.Content: I have the original first-gen Fire, and this looked like a good upgrade, and so far, so good. I'm posting this as 4-stars, minus one star for reasons I'll explain below. Some of my points will be comparing it to the original Fire.First up, it is noticeably lighter than the original Fire, and the beveled edges make it a bit easier to hold. There is a bizarrely angled port for the power charger, in that it does not sit flush with the Fire, and you kinda have to keep this in mind when plugging it in. I am mildly concerned that the power cable will experience stress, especially in a situation when I am using it while charging it. It just seems like a weird thing.Setting it up was pretty easy, just a few steps, log in to your Amazon account, and it automatically populates the carousel with my recently read books, in the proper order. I used the Silk browser for a while, and it is very nice; it is a full blown browser, not the "mobile" browser that I've seen on various Android devices. Pinch-n-zoom, slide-n-scroll, all the navigation people are probably already familiar with. If not, it doesn't take long to get used to it.I did look at some prior reviews just now, and see a lot of people mention the "purple haze", and unfortunately for me, now that I've read about it, I see the same effect on my HDX. It is mostly apparent in certain lighting situations, such as the reading books, when the screen is mostly white. I watched several hours of anime and did not notice anything at the time. It does not seem to be apparent on the home screen or a few other places, which makes me wonder if this is just a possible software fix.Battery life seems pretty good. When I first got it out of the box, it was at 60% charge, and it did not take very long to top it off. I did not time anything, so I can only offer subjective impressions. I watched at least 18 25-minute videos before I felt the battery was depleted enough to need a recharge, but it was not less than 25%, and I could have squeaked more non-video usage out of it.Speaking of video, this new HDX has the option to download Prime videos. I mean, you can watch them for free via Prime, but to actually download them? That's a new thing on me. I ended up downloading 14 episodes, one right after the other. Those videos take up a bit under 2gb of memory. Seems pretty good.Edit: I forgot to mention that the speakers are very nice compared to the original Fire. While using the first-gen Fire to watch videos, one of the first things I felt I needed was a set of external speakers. Once you start adding external accessories to a supposedly portable device, well, you kinda lose something in that process. The HDX speakers are very nice, crisp and loud enough that I don't feel the need for external speakers.The video app is very fickle for me. I selected the series I wanted to watch, which was an anime with 25 episodes. After watching two in a row, I need to take a break, so I put the HDX down on the table and come back in an hour or so. Restarting the HDX shows the series on the carousal, but when I click on the icon, it gives me a spinning cursor icon and waits forever, and never actually loads the video list. I timed 10 minutes on this behavior once. I've tried disconnecting/reconnecting to wi-fi, rebooting, etc, and can't determine why this happens. And it _only_ happens with the video app. Everything else is snappy as I could hope. I know it is not my WiFi, which is a dual-band BG/N router. Connecting at N speeds, I get 75% signal strength. Dropping down to BG speeds gives me full strength. But either way, signal strength is strong enough, and everything else works as expected, so that I know it is not latency that causes this. It is something with the way Amazon remembers where I stopped off, caching my last viewed video and position in the video. Even going into the previously downloaded content exhibits this behavior.Edit: if I force-kill the Amazon Video app, this behavior is no longer apparent, so I still feel confident in my suspicion that it is something software-wise, or something with Amazon's services, and unrelated to user error.So long story short, I find it is a minor flawed upgrade, but one still worth perusing.

Reviews.Title: Great Upgrade from the HD
Reviews.Author: Willy Wailer
Reviews.Content: This is my 6th Kindle and my third Fire having started with the original. Everything written about the advances of the X over the HD are correct. It is very fast, great screen, lighter, etc. I use Kindles primarily as a book reader and a secondary computer to my laptop. As to the boarder surrounding book text; it does not bother me what so ever. In the `white' mode, I find the text is embedded in very slight parchment color with a boarder of off white surrounding the text. I rather like the effect. Well worth the price to upgrade from the HD.

Reviews.Title: Blue/Purple glow around edges :(
Reviews.Author: Randall
Reviews.Content: Just got my Kindle Fire HDX 7 inch today, and sure enough as others here as well as bloggers have pointed out, there is a serious design flaw (probably because the same company makes it as makes the Kindle Paperwhite which I also own and that also has that blue glow but at least the paperwhite is cheap)-- the purple/blue glow around the edges. Very annoying when trying to read a book. I will likely be returning this; I paid $324 for this and that is just too much money to justify a design flaw. I had such excitement and hopes for the HDX. I really wanted to like this small lighter weight tablet, hoping I could use it for a color ereader. But not at the price with such a design flaw. I don't trust a replacement unit to be sent considering how widespread this problem seems to be, as any replacement unit I were to get might start showing the purple after the window for returning it were to close. Sigh. It is a nice little tablet otherwise, or so it appears, but I can not justify 3 stars ("Okay") because it is not okay to pay $324 and be stuck with a tablet ereader with purple-blue glowing all around the ebook page edge.EDIT: I just boxed up the HDX and will be returning it tomorrow. I also noticed that blue/purple fringe on webpages, again very annoying. Also the page curl feature when turning pages of an ebook was not working-- yes i had that setting turned on (I checked) and yes i tried it on about six random ebooks of mine that I purchased through amazon. I checked other [non-kindle] tablets at the local store today and they did not have that blue fringe glow, in fact the original Kindle HD was a clean white; seems to be in the HDX line as well as the Kindle Paperwhite (which as I said I decided to keep as it is so lightweight and I like the backlighting). Anyhow my dreams of an HDX are shattered, back to square one.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Caleb
Reviews.Content: I read several "Kindle Fire vs Nexus 7" comparisons before deciding to purchase the kindle fire hdx 7" based on the consensus that, while they were very similar, the audio and the processing power were better on the kindle. I purchased this as a birthday present for my wife, and she would primarily use it, like most people, for streaming video content. She watches a lot of youtube. Even knowing that the amazon app store didn't have everything the google play store provides, it never occurred to me that YouTube wouldn't be supported. They advertise as having superior content availability, yet don't support one of the most popular video-streaming apps out there. My wife and myself don't download many apps, so I assumed the limited app selection wouldn't be a big drawback for us - also assuming that all the *most* popular apps would still be available. I assumed incorrectly. And now I'm considering returning this because its app store is, in fact, lacking more than they tell you about.

Reviews.Title: Easy to get started
Reviews.Author: Ancient Mariner
Reviews.Content: But then I began to wonder what I was going to use this thing for. I am not a "phone thumbs" person, I don't "face" or "tweet" (although I do belch once in a while), and I have no real desire to play run and dodge games.  The little rectangular thing is growing on me though. I like the un-complex silk browser and have found some apps that I can use for reference material. I have streamed a couple of movies with no glitches (7" screen) and have read a half dozen or so books.  I signed up for a year of Prime to see what content I can get. So far I have had no problems and I am very far from being a "techie". The one thing I find bothersome is that so many of the apps want personal information apparently for marketing purposes.

Reviews.Title: inexpensive tablet
Reviews.Author: Zachary Vicha
Reviews.Content: I got this instead of an iPad. I'm very pleased with it, especially it as a reader. I like it's built-in Amazon interface. Definitely pay to not have the ads.

Reviews.Title: Not a Full Feature Tablet, But......
Reviews.Author: Mark L. Zimmerman
Reviews.Content: Okay, so let's acknowledge right from the start that this is not a full featured tablet.  If that is going to bother you, look at the Nexus.  I use a MotoX for my mobile phone, and really like the features and functionality of it.  I have virtually all of the same apps loaded onto my Kindle that I have on my MotoX.  Whatever apps I don't have available, I don't miss.  I knew going in that I would be using this device for entertainment and for really quick access to weather apps, email and eCommerce sites.  The screen looks amazing and the sound is awesome.  The biggest negative I have is that you can't use flash player.  That's not Amazon's fault or oversight, that's just the Android incompatibility.  I don't need this particular functionality with most of the streaming content I wish to view.  But if that is a deal breaker for you, then just take that into account.  Otherwise, I am very happy with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great Product For Right Consumer
Reviews.Author: Katt Winter
Reviews.Content: I am a techie, and an Amazon Prime lover. I own a Note 3, MSI GT70, Ipad4, Note 10.1 2014, and a few older tablets for reading including an underwhelming 2012 HD refurbished Kindle. I was annoyed with the old HD for many reasons and was going to return it until my son stole it for Kindle Free Time, which btw, is worth the subscription. However, as many people do who don't have multiple screen homes (Kindle HD 2012 was first and only at the time) I was annoyed by its limits and didn't see it's merits.Even with my plethora of fancy and infancy devices I missed Amazon's set up for books and video streaming. I could have got the all new version of the HD cheaply but I thought for a few dollars more having the most recent Kindle would've hurt, would have all the product support (os updates, lending library, and Prime HD streams). However, what I didn't know about was the free Prime downloads they added!!!!!Unfortunately this feature will only be amazingly useful on Kindle with higher memory. It makes me want to cry. :( If you want to store your music and have up to four or so 1080p movies downloaded for offline use 16 gigs is too small. It's the case for any tablet, and to be honest 32 is really very little. The os your apps and games will eat that space in no time. It's not like the olden days.Aside from the os eating all my space, I have to say if you're a Prime Member the HDX is a need. It's so lovely watching videos for free that were optimized for your device in impressive full 1080p. I had no idea how useful this would be for more than a bedside companion. No 4G or purchases necessary to enjoy a show while you're waiting at the doctor. In that respect alone, if you're a loyal Amazon subscriber regardless of the tablet this is a no brained thing you will enjoy.The old HD lags and is slow, but this model is fast. You can write accurately and with ease. The battery life might make you sad, but if you're reading I believe you have 17 hours. Which, is totally why you own a fire right? ;)The app store is still limited, and behind ios and android in updates and releases, but Amazon is working on getting exclusive games for its tablet owners like the Telltale Walking Dead series. Which is amazing...I'm pregnant and struggling with a lot of physical issues and have been confined to my bed so gadgets have become very important. I doubt I could rationalize spending $300 of tech money on an 8.9 or even a 7 inch HDX when for that I could purchase a Nexus 10 or 7, or even a used retina ipad mini, but I can't say I don't want one. (There is one on my wishlist).If you're new to technology and tablets you will love an HDX, if you're a loyal Amazon Prime fan and use their wonderful services then you will enjoy this. It's fast. So fast, and streams in true HD with proper broadband connection so you will only miss the downloads when you're mobile. We all know Kindle Ebooks beat all other ebooks, and Amazon makes the best reading app. It's still an impressive ereader, and the Goodreads integration makes my nerdy soul happy.Cons are it's still a bit heavy for a reader, but a nice case with a strap should remedy that. No back camera, so if this is going to be your main tablet you will be saddened. No HDMI port but those are becoming dinosaur tech, and adapters or Miracast exists now for older tv's. No Google Play store... But I have to say something as a techie dork. Amazon I hope you're listening, you guys almost have it right. What do I mean?You're providing great hardware for discounted prices and adding amazing customer service to your product for no additional cost. *Slow Clap* You're producing Amazon Exclusive content that is available only on your devices, but you allow other devices access to your main features so you're not self isolating either like Apple can.The HDX is truly a step in the right direction of you guys can do the following:Open The Play Store. Trust your products and store, it's great. Apps are discounted, and fair. Limiting yourself in this area is hurting you. I believe you'll see the errors of your ways here. Have exclusive content and offer your own, and win the internet even more than you already have.Step the prices down for the bigger memory tablets. You're not selling machines, you're selling a portal to one of the best services out there. I save so much money using your physical stores alone!! Your videos are beautifully optimized. Your tablets are now impressive, and no one can best your customer service for the services you provide. So, since you're selling physical products, movies, and exclusive content take a bit more of a hit on them HDX tablets so the service is available to more people everywhere.Allow us to customize the carousel. We know it's a Kindle, but give us some options. Let us display a book collection up there instead of all the recently opened things. Remove from carousel is one of my least favorite things. I don't mind the special offers, because there are great deals and recommendations there but allow us some level of customization and I don't mean those weird decals.Let Google into your hearts all the way. Give us a normal page or two with widgets. I love the folders feature.If you made those tweaks your tablet might win the internet completely. (Maybe usb 3.0 too)That all being said this is a great tablet for Prime members, readers, and streamers. The 16 gig HDX is worth keeping around for a long time, and I believe newbies and tech lovers alike will be happy with the hardware.If this is your only tab expect app store limits and some frustrations, but Amazon is really working to improve those things, and HDX owners will reap the benefits of this in the future. Music sounds great for back speakers and is the best I've heard from any non Bluetooth connected tablet yet. Price is still good. May Day is useful for even the savviest of us because it saves time. If you're not going to be a Prime Member, you want the biggest selection of apps and all of their updates immediately and this is going to be your main and only device... you're not a reader... or you're looking for a productivity or Jack of all trades machine this isn't for you. Don't buy it then give it a horrible review. This is a media tab. Movies, music, books, and shopping. All the best things in life. It does do some productivity but if that's what you need look elsewhere.When you pick up an HDX you're picking up well crafted fun. The pixels are so pretty you'll want to shed a tear. Amazon's media access is so extensive you'll want for little, and combined with other services, you may just want for nothing.If you get an HDX no matter what you will find things that will bring you joy, hopefully for a few years to come. I wish I paid full price for device help if it malfunctions (they all do) because dealing with Amazon directly is usually a dream, but I got a great deal. I am absolutely pleasantly surprised and taken with this device, and I think you will be too if this is what you choose for your ereading and Amazon media needs.

Reviews.Title: Small software glitch found with Skype and Kindle FreeTime.
Reviews.Author: eddiebauer24
Reviews.Content: I would give this a 5 star rating if it wasn't for the problems I have had with getting Skype to work.  So a little background on me, I work internationally and bought three KF HDX 7" for my three daughters.  One of the main reasons I got them the tablets is so that they can Skype with me while I am out of the country.After an hour of troubleshooting with the tech rep (which was probably the fastest response I have ever gotten from technical support), we were able to get Skype going in the parental section of the tablets.  However the plan for me is that the kids will never be in that section of the tablet.  I have subscribed to the Kindle FreeTime App and this is the only additional app that I have added to this section.Another two hours with another tech rep, and I am still not able to use Skype while in the FreeTime mode.  Currently the problem is being escalated up to another level of tech support.  This very issue is common on all three Kindles that are sitting in front of me.Other than this one issue, I would have to give the tablet a clear 5 star as it is as described by Amazon.  And with tech support like they are offering, the other tablet manufacturers had better watch and learn.Edit:  Got a call from Amazon Customer care and it seem that their engineers are aware that Skype is one of the Apps that conflicts with the settings of the FreeTime environment and as such causes the App to crash.  There is supposed to be a fix being worked on here in the near future and released for wide distribution.  In the mean time I guess I will just keep to skyping on the PC.  Peace and Bacon Grease!!!

Reviews.Title: Exceptional quality and out of the box true plug and play. Get one today!
Reviews.Author: James Smart Sr.
Reviews.Content: I placed my order on November 15th and received it on November 18th. quick service from the start. Just plain exceptional product!  This is my first tablet and it has been a pleasant surprise. I looked at the best of the bunch and best priced. I read the reviews and selected from the "Kindle Fire" lineup. Price with features lead me to going with the Hdx 7" 32 gb. I ordered a "Moko" case and the 2- year warranty with it. What worried me was some of the reviews on the site. I am 63 years old but I love technology and I can usually compete with the best. Some of the less than favorable reviews were a possible worry.Everyone, put your mind at ease, Amazon has set the highest of standards and come through with the best in every way. This product was truly plug and play. The reading experience is better than all others. The responsiveness of the screen in speed and visual imaging render web surfing and video watching a great experience even on a small screen. The light weight of the Kindle Hdx and size gives it a good feel in your hands. I highly recommend this tablet as a best buy of exceptional quality.

Reviews.Title: mayday button or mom-away button hmmm ???
Reviews.Author: adrian duran
Reviews.Content: this was a birthday gift for my mom. i bought this for her because she is elderly and the mayday is perfect for her , plus my sanitystays intact  not trying to teach her how to use it over the phone. yah for me!  sounds like a great commercial to me what you think?as for the 4 out of 5 is because i did not spend a lot of time with the device , although i did notice plugging into the device was hard see and it went in on a weird angle that part i did not like .

Reviews.Title: This is the Kindle Fire we've been waiting for
Reviews.Author: Kha Le
Reviews.Content: I love Amazon but must admit I've always been a little disappointed in their Fire series.I got the original Kindle Fire back in 2011 - loved the concept but not the performance or hardware.Gave them another shot last year with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" - awesome screen but had major memory issues. A little too heavy and awkward to use as a reader and ended up being used as my night-time Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime video player.Now for this years Kindle Fire HDX - simply blown away. I've taken this guy everywhere with me for the past week and it's been a pleasure. For the first time on the Fire series I don't have ANY complaints. My only regret is I probably should have waited a month for the 4G version with Verizon Wireless.

Reviews.Title: Love my kindle fire HDX
Reviews.Author: Susanna "sue shipman"
Reviews.Content: I bought this kindle so I could watch my movies, read my books. listen to my audio books, listen to my music, skype my grandchildren, play free cell, and read my e-mail. I have been more than pleased wit this product. I just love it! I also recommended it to friends. I have kindle on my laptop, but have always had trouble with trying to download my movies. And it is too cumbersome to read books or listen to music, esp in the evening when I like to listen w ear phones so I don"t disturb my husband. I am just so thrilled and have not encountered sny problems with it.

Reviews.Title: Review on Fire HDX.....7 inch model
Reviews.Author: Roxy Drew
Reviews.Content: I love how Amazon makes it affordable for even poor people to get the newest technology.The new Fire has higher volume in the headset department.Might not seem like much,but for hearing impaired people like me,it's a plus!The colors on the book covers are outstanding and vivid and clearly stand out.I like how light it is to hold.Every year Amazon makes new customers by their outstanding products!And the old customers like me,will never leave them..Amazon has never let me down,and my whole family and I,are proud kindle users:)

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HDX is great
Reviews.Author: sado
Reviews.Content: The HDX is much faster in all respects than the HD.  the only problem ive had is that some of the apps i used to have on my HD no longer work on the HDX, but im sure it will be ironed out.  Wonderful for reading books as well.  The new screen is sweet too.  now just release the amazon set top box and everyone will be happy!

Reviews.Title: Wow!
Reviews.Author: J. Bodie
Reviews.Content: Amazing advances from the Fire HD. The speed is wonderful.  Silk browser is a pleasure to use. The screen is just beautiful. Colors are rich and edges are sharp. This is a great device at an exceptional price.

Reviews.Title: Sharp display that rivals Kindle Paperwhites (but in color)
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: As background, tablets that I have used/experimented include Kindle Fire (1st Gen), Fire HD 7" and 8.9", iPad 1 and 4 Retna, Nexus 7, Surface Pro, and Thinkpad Helix. I do pay for Amazon Prime membership as well as Kindle Freetime Unlimited for kids.Ok, with that out of the way, allow me to share with you my impressions:Device layout/Handling-----------------------WEIGHT: It feels really light! I measured on my digital scale which showed 10.6oz (300g)VOLUME CONTROL: I actually like the volume up/down on the back where my right fingers can conveniently adjust without losing grip. If these buttons can be re-mapped, then racing games will be at another level with "paddle shifters!"POWER BUTTON: I am neutral on its location (left rear). Users can get confused with volume buttons on the other side. Also, once the Origami case is put on, there would not be a need to hit the power button at all since opening/closing cover will do the job automagically.Display/Audio--------------TEXT: very sharp - can see the difference with its improved pixel density. Not sure it'll help improve the reader's vision, but certainly it is very pleasant and easy on the eye. Almost as pleasant as Kindle Paperwhites, but with color!VIDEO: I side-loaded a 1080p movie clip, and it looked real good as it should. Most people will not put big 1080p movies with 16-32GB storage. Downloaded 720p HD videos are fine, but they won't blow anyone away compared to similar tablets on the market.GRAPHICS: very smooth and clean rendering with no lag for fast action games like Real Racing 3 and Asphalt 8. Icons for Apps, movies, and music albums all look sharper. The only negative I found with such high resolution is some older color kids books are image-based, so a full page on older Kindle Fire now look tiny on the HDX display.AUDIO: Very impressive stereo fidelity! I can hear the pleasant difference compare to the Fire HD, but may not be as loud. Sound reflects nicely when laid flat on my kitchen counter.CAMERA: only front-facing camera which looks fine with proper lighting. Nothing breakthrough here. Maybe someday there can be a nigh-vision camera as part of the x-ray feature set...LOLBattery Life--------------STANDBY: full to drained in 4 days - just under 100 hours with email and notification check once a day.ACTIVE USE: I got past 6 hours of web browsing, listen to music, and watching videos before I had to retire (approx 50% juice left)Software/System----------------STABILITY: no hang-and-reboot has occurred so far. This happened a few times on my Fire HD. The pad is warm to touch after a while but not hot.WI-FI/Bluetooth: works well like the Fire HDs.X-Ray: Music lyrics is very cool and I love it. This feature shows up on many of the MP3 albums purchased from Amazon. Usefulness in Kindle books depend on the content. Movies? Works like having an interactive blu-ray session, which I don't find it as useful. As expected, my personal uploaded music are not "x-rayed" for lyrics.QUIET TIME: Saw "Quiet Time" button next to "Mayday" and didn't know what it is, so I pressed "Mayday" to find out. Quiet time is to "mute" notification and others that cause audibles, but does not mute the sound from music, games, or other apps.MAYDAY: got a male operator within 15 seconds. He did require me to verify my email address, name on the account, and billing address. I asked him how would my kids be able to use this feature when I issue them the new Kindle HDX?  He said "good question" and will pass it on...So just a heads-up that the operator will need certain info.SILK: Browser runs fast as is. This is NOT always the case with Fire HD, where the browser can crawl like a turtle unless the "Accelerate Page Loading" is turned off. So looks like the developers fixed this to perform as advertised. I hope that will give Fire HD's software an update also.Summary--------For Kindle users: The HDX is a good incremental upgrade to Fire HD. The major improvements underneath don't surface as much for general users. But for owners of the first generation Kindle Fire, upgrade to HDX is significant.For non Kindle tablet owners: Kindle devices greatly enhance experience with Amazon's offerings with e-books, music hosting, instant videos, magazines, and especially for Prime members. If you are into Amazon's online services, this Kindle will provide greater value.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful and flawed.
Reviews.Author: B. Wertz "Imautobot"
Reviews.Content: I really really wanted to like this Kindle.  I bought it as a upgrade from a 2012 Google Nexus 7.  This was a mistake.At first I did this because I am a Prime member, and an Amazon device is really the only way to get access to the streaming video on a tablet, or the lending library option.  However, these additional options do not make up for what I lost.  By this I mean, I can't (easily) get any Google apps installed on the device.  If you want a legitimate version of any Google product, or many other Google play apps, you cannot install it without a side-load situation.  My problem with that is that apks are then downloaded by non-store sites, this means they might be out of date, or even hacked.  I chose the path of least resistance and just sent it back.  I've got better things to do with my time that hack a product right out of the box.  While this means you don't get access to the actual G-mail app, Google Earth, Google+, and YouTube, the loss that hurt me the most was the inability to install Chrome.  Chrome has all my bookmarks, and I had little desire to painstakingly re-enter all those into the silk browser.The hardware is nice, the interface runs smooth, and the high res icons that consume the better part of the main menu are surprisingly beautiful.  However, I found it annoying that under those icons, you'll be force fed amazon purchase suggestions based upon on what icon is centered.  I bought the Kindle without the "special offers" for a reason, so this subtle solicitation bothered me.Ultimately the Kindle feels only slightly less locked down than an iPhone/iPad, which is exactly the same reason why I don't buy those Apple products.  I want my device to be free to get apps from multiple (legitimate) sources.  And I want that functionality to exist out of the box.  It's interesting that my Nexus 7 can easily get the Amazon app store installed, but the Kindle could not easily have given me access to the Google Play store.I ended up replacing this with a Nexus 7 2013, which lamentably has a slightly slower processor, but at least I'm not in for any of these proprietary surprises.  Maybe I've just been spoiled by my other Android devices.If Kindle allows Google apps to be able to be installed through a front-door option, I would gladly revisit the Kindle hardware, it is still a nice piece of equipment.

Reviews.Title: No regrets
Reviews.Author: BW
Reviews.Content: I recently upgraded to the HDX from the HD. I was reluctant to order because of the blue haze issue reported in other posts but decided to trust Amazon's explanation and order one. My new HDX does have a little blue haze around the edges but to tell you the truth I may not have noticed if I had not already known to look for it. I like the easy access to all of the controls (power and speaker volume), the lighter weight and smaller size and the smoother operation of the device. Web pages display faster and I actually think the speaker volume and audio quality is better than the fire HD. Glad I upgraded.

Reviews.Title: Mayday option is awesome!
Reviews.Author: Linda G
Reviews.Content: This is a great device for someone who has trouble getting around the internet. The Mayday feature is awesome. Gave to my 92 year old husband and he loves it.

Reviews.Title: Had to return the device as a result of intermittent network problems
Reviews.Author: Marc Dulude
Reviews.Content: I got the Kindle with much anticipation and had problems with the installation right from the start.  I used the Mayday button and that worked very well to get somebody on the line but it seemed that they hadn't really done anything and the problem had just gone away.  Undeterred, I continued to use the Kindle and load more apps and media.  Then, I would be unable to connect to the network when all my other devices were working fine.  I had to use the Kindle support number since the device wasn't working and they had me take the network down and reset everything even though all my other devices worked.  I reset to factory defaults (twice) and tried multiple times to watch videos but it would just show the spinning dial.  I tried getting to the lending library and it showed as unavailable.  Special offers were no longer available and so on and so on and the message said I needed to have the device registered (it was and confirmed by Amazon) and a working network (here we go again).Each deficient item eventually came back to a working state but never as a result of anything the support people were having me do.  I lost patience and returned the device.

Reviews.Title: I really like the Kindle Fire HDX
Reviews.Author: JennGB
Reviews.Content: I bought the HDX as an upgrade - replacing my 2011 Kindle Fire.  Overall I'm very pleased with the device.  Here are the best things about it (in my opinion):1)  Noticeably faster than my old tablet2)  Flatter/lighter/easier to hold for long periods of time3) Better placement of power button and headphone jack4) Manual on-exterior-of-device volume control (instead of having to go through settings, etc.)5)  Email is better in every conceivable way!6) Much more storage7) better sound8) less clunky OS than the original Fire9) easy to switch quickly from one app to anotherHonestly, the only reason I'm not giving the device 5 stars is because I don't like the blue LED bleed around the edges (sometimes referred to as the "blue haze" by other reviewers) when viewing something with a light background.  I read on my device a lot and it is very noticeable (and I feel quite distracting) in both the black-on-white and brown-on-sepia settings.  On my device the bleed is noticeable all the way around and is wider on the long sides (measures about 1/4 of an inch) but thinner (about 1/8 of an inch) on the short sides.  I used the Mayday button (which is a really nifty feature, by the way) and was told that this was normal and that there was nothing I could do about it.  I find this pretty disappointing, but it isn't a deal-breaker for me - I'm not going to reject it and return it for a refund due to the blue haze issue (though if they manage to come up with some sort of update that would fix/improve it, I'd be the first to get that update!).That said, I'd still recommend this tablet to people - particularly if they use it more for non-reading activities.  Overall I'm happy with my upgrade.P.s.  I also bought the plastic version of the origami cover and I can't recommend it enough.  It makes using the device twice as enjoyable!

Reviews.Title: A Very Nice Update of the Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: MrSteveP
Reviews.Content: I recently gave my Kindle Fire HD to my Nephew so I would have an excuse to purchase the Fire HDX. I am well pleased with the new device. The graphics are amazing whether watching Prime or You Tube videos as well as viewing web sites or playing games. The new processor is extremely snappy and executes loading and running apps very fast. I have no issue with the blue haze issue on the edge of the display. I understand the reasons for the blue LED use and accept Amazons explanation. It is a non issue, really. I read quite a bit on the Kindle HDX on a plain white screen then a sepia screen and was not distracted. Again, it is on the very edges where no text appears. It is nonexistent on videos, dark backgrounds, etc. I did try the Mayday function with a question and it was promptly answered and frankly, this is a really progressive implementation of customer service/tech support. Very nice job Amazon. The curated appstore is obviously not as complete as Google Play but has anything important and then some. I do not feel the need to sideload apps whatsoever. The essentials are more than covered and then some. For the record I also own the Google Nexus 7 2nd Gen and think these are two great devices. I'm fully invested in the Amazon ecosystem with books, MP3's, apps and videos and like having a dedicated device. The Nexus 7 can do all the same things by running Amazon Apps except there is no App for Amazon Instant Video. The IOS (ipad, iphone) has such an app, but not android. All told I have the best of both worlds and didn't break the bank to do so. If you are on the fence I don't think you can lose either way. The biggest differences are No Google Play on the Fire HDX, and no Amazon Instant Video on the Nexus 7. Faster quad core processor on the Fire HDX and brighter screen on the Nexus 7. There is a sense of community with Amazon that is really an intangible and keeps me loyal to this company. Not to mention the great shopping experience with Prime, although this has nothing to do with the tablet. You'll like the Kindle Fire HDX. It is a fast and responsive device.After using the Fire HDX for a week I am discovering that there is a compatibility issue with certain apps that I used on my Kindle Fire HD but will not run on the Fire HDX. Two apps in particular, Tune in Radio and Optimum TV app cannot run on the HDX. I am awaiting an update of the app or the HDX to remedy this. Hopefully this is a temporary situation. Meanwhile I have to nick 1 star off my review.Nov 12, 2013 Update: App compatibility has been addressed. Tune In Radio & Optimum TV are both working great. Review now upped to full 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: So far so good...
Reviews.Author: Afobos
Reviews.Content: Okay, I'm giving it 5 stars on a trial basis.  I have until the 22nd of November to return it for a refund, and if nothing goes wrong I won't be coming back to subtract stars.  The reason for my weariness is because I had to send the first on back due to issues and here they are:  1st everyone else and their Grandma was complaining about the blue or purple haze around the edge of the white page when you're reading.  I noticed that on mine as well but honestly it's not that noticeable and not distracting at least to me.  There are varying opinions even among the techs at amazon I spoke with as to whether this is intended or a flaw.  2nd while I was reading, the page would blank out for a second or two once in a long while.  That I didn't like.  3d Another issue was the fact that certain parts of my screen where sluggish to respond to touch.  That tore it and I had to exchange it.  I spoke with tech support through the mayday function, but all I got was a picture and no video like they said.There was an update that would not download, and I had the device for 2 days.  All that time the update bar never moved.One thing that surprised me was the cheap packaging the first kindle arrived in.  It came in a cushioned mailing envelope and the kindle was sliding around inside.  I thought that was kind of a cheesy way to ship a $300.00 device, and I was happy to see that yesterday when my new one arrived it came in a very well cushioned sturdy box which I appreciated a lot more than the cheesy cushioned envelope the first one came in.  I wouldn't be surprised if some of the issues I was having were due to the kindle being banged around by ups personnel playing football with it.  As usual Amazon was very cooperative and they rushed me another one in a couple of days.  I received the new one yesterday, and I still see the blue haze around the page, but like I said that doesn't bother me.  I usually read with the black backdrop and white letters in any case.  Everything else on this one is running smoothly so far, but it's on probation.  I'm giving it 5 stars because so far everything on it works like it's supposed to.  I used the mayday function on it a couple of times and it only took a few seconds for a live video of the tech to pop up on my screen which I found pretty cool and very helpful.  So far I find it to be a 5 star device, but like I said, I'm going to give it a month and see if I have to come back and change my review or not.  I'm hoping not because I really like it, and hope it stays like it is.  The high definition is amazing, and so far the only thing I haven't tried is the Skype function due to the fact that I don't feel like blowing more money on something I really don't need because you have to purchase time with them like you would with a cell phone company.  Something to consider maybe in the future.  I opted for the one with the ads but they don't bother me in the least, and you only see them when you are turning your device on.  I also have the one with the 64 gbs which is a definite improvement over my first generation kindle which this one is replacing.Overall I think it's a great device, and I've checked out ipads, and I'm glad I've got this instead of one of the overpriced super hyped ipads.  You're on probation kindle HDX until the 22nd of November!  Ok, here it is November 7th, and I've had my new kindle now for a while and I just thought I'd come back and add something I don't like about it.  I thought of subtracting a star because of these two reasons, but the good outweigh the bad (at least in my opinion) and here are the two reasons why I almost subtracted a star:First there is no light indicating when your kindle is fully charged.  You have to turn your kindle on to see if it's finished charging.  Why get rid of the light indicator?  Did it really take up that much space?Second: Why are the speakers in the back and not in the front?  It sounds a hell of a lot better when you turn your kindle backwards and listen to it.  Then you can't see the video.  Come on Amazon!  You've made a killer device and it could have been a lot better by adding a charge indicator light and moving the speakers to where they should be!  I'm leaving it at 5 stars because everything else is awesome!

Reviews.Title: OUTSTANDING!!!!
Reviews.Author: golfman
Reviews.Content: I have been a Kindle Fire owner since they were first introduced, and as pleased as I am with my Fire, I thought when I read the introduction email about the HDX that it offered many upgrades that sounded great.  Well all I can say is that I couldn't be more pleased with my new HDX. I have used it in every way and with a variety of applications and the subject of this review "OUTSTANDING"is the truest complement I can give it.  You can't find a product at this price level that will provide a better "bang for your buck". This is a "5" Star above rating.Thank you

Reviews.Title: Mainly Amazon Services Centric
Reviews.Author: Roberto
Reviews.Content: I'll start by saying Amazon expected their apps and services to be part of the Google Play and Apple App Stores, yet they do not let you install any Google Apps or services on their devices. Also by limiting the apps you can install from a lot of developers they limit the use of it; this renders the Kindle useless for the work environment. And there are plenty of fun apps that cannot be installed. (I do not care for rooting, I believe the device should work great on it's own without having to experiment with it).I'm on my third Kindle, the first one the screen flickered, but I now realize they all do to some degree. (My first one was noticeable to the people around me though). The second Kindle the battery stopped holding a charge.I have to say I was very excited and looked forward to receiving my first Kindle HDX, but sad to say I was very disappointed as Amazon markets the Kindle as being able to hold it's own in the working environment, but it does not. And by now I highly question their quality, unless in my case I just have really bad luck.The Kindle HDX is perfect for the Prime member (which I am), and now realize it is mainly designed for this purpose.I enjoy the integration with my Prime Membership, but disappointed it mainly stays by my bedside table now.

Reviews.Title: Yeah, no...
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: Sorry Amazon, love you as a store, but your tablet is WAY too proprietary! This is not a true android device; it may have that at its core, somewhere, but there's just too much "Amazon shell" between the user and the OS; it can't play anything off google play, can't even access it without a 3rd party app, many android apps have issues or won't run due to not having google services installed... this feels less like a tablet and more like a "Amazon Store Shopping Companion"; everything on it is geared towards helping people buy products from Amazon, rather than enjoying the freedom and open-source nature of Android.

Reviews.Title: Broke within the first few days
Reviews.Author: Ubaldo
Reviews.Content: Three days after purchasing this Kindle the touch screen stopped working. One side of the screen does not work, so in order to type anything my daughter has to constantly flip the Kindle around to where the letters on the keyboard are on the functioning side of the Kindle. I regret purchasing this product.

Reviews.Title: Long Time Apple Ipad User Amazed by Kindle HDX That Costs a Third As Much
Reviews.Author: Pod
Reviews.Content: I love the HDX.  I got it on special for $154 and at that price it's a freaking bargain.  I am a  longtime Ipad user (Ipad 2 and more recently Ipad Air) but I was looking for something more portable I could take on my subway ride to work and I didn't want to drop $400 for an Ipad Mini.  What really sold me on the HDX was that I could download free content from Prime and then watch that on the train and I would be able to use the device as a very portable reader.  I was expecting a significant downgrade from my Ipad Air in performance but have found myself blown away by:1. Feel:  The device is light, well built and has good tactile feel with a grippy, rubber like backing.  I bought a case (10 bucks) which was fine but I really liked holding the device without protection so I ditched it.2. Picture:  The picture quality for videos is amazing, far surpassing the Ipad Air's (or any other display I've seen):  I downloaded and watched (for free) an episode of Justified and was noticing slight blemishes and beads of sweat on people's faces.  The images are simply beautiful.3.  Performance:  The HDX is snappy with no lag whatsoever and very intuitive functionality. I was even able to side load a nook app and other Google Play apps in a matter of minutes following easy instructions on line.4.  Browser:  Silk is very quick and easy to use and works like Chrome (which can also be sideloaded but I prefer Silk)5. Customer Support: The Mayday function is revolutionary.  I have never waited more than 30 seconds for help and every rep has been friendly and competent (and native English speakers).  They have walked me through the necessary steps, drawing and highlighting on my unit, and even provided additional tips and suggestions.  Like others I had some issues with dropped WI-FI signals but the Mayday rep downloaded a WI-FI manager for me that maximizes the signal strength from my router and I haven't had a dropped signal since then, about a week ago.  One Mayday rep I spoke to said they spend a lot of time helping folks with basic non-HDX-specific functions on third party apps like Facebook or email like posting pictures or attaching documents.  The Mayday reps are also Amazon generalists and can handle customer service issues as well.6. Cloud storage: This was something I wasn't even aware of when I purchased the unit but copying photos from my Mac and music from Itunes into the Amazon cloud and onto the device was easy and free (2GB for photos and 250 songs).  I also have all my Nook books on the unit which I didn't know was something I could do.In summary I am very impressed with my HDX.  It's a very capable, inexpensive little device.  It won't replace my Ipad use at home but it's perfect for commuting and travelling places where I don't want to carry a larger device.  I have since purchased one for my mom for Mother's Day.  I originally purchased the Fire for her but the Mayday button would be so helpful for her, particularly with everyday functions like how to use Facebook, that I returned the Fire and upgraded to HDX.In brief response to comments from some of the the other reviewers: it is true that the universe of available apps is smaller than on Google Play or Itunes.  That's not really Amazon's fault and most Google Play apps can be side loaded with third-party software. The critical apps are all there.  Also, as other reviewers have noted, the HDX can drop WI-FI signals.  As discussed above, Amazon is aware of the issue and, according to the Mayday rep I spoke with, is working on a fix to be released with the next software update.  In the meantime, the third-party WiFi manager the rep downloaded onto my unit has worked perfectly.

Reviews.Title: Dissapointing technical support
Reviews.Author: Larry Sassaman
Reviews.Content: I purchased the HDX in early Dec. 2013 and until last week was very pleased with the Kindle's performance. Last week my HDX began shutting down and restarting for no reason and has continued to do so through the present. I've spoken to 3 different technical representatives about the problem and they have no solution to my dilemma in almost a week. All they can tell me is they're working on the problem. I've checked online forums and other people are reporting the same problem so this is not something which is unique to my Kindle. I expected a better response from Amazon. Update: It's now 2 weeks since I notified Amazon of the problem with my Kindle Fire HDX and they still have not offered any solution to the problem. When I called them 5 days ago for an update all they could tell me was that they were still studying the problem. Maybe they need an SOS button instead of just Mayday. Get with it Amazon !!!!!

Reviews.Title: More trouble!!!!
Reviews.Author: John Pattenger
Reviews.Content: Second kindle HD ... first one didn't work properly...Now this one is messed up. Shuts itself down while I'm reading and reboots itself. Almost impossible to read in sunlight. You would think they would combine the best of previous kindles.

Reviews.Title: Not as good as original Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: kt "k"
Reviews.Content: I already have a Kindle Fire and bought the Fire HDX because it has a camera and allows me to skype (which the original Fire does not).  I love Kindle, however the HDX runs down the battery sooooo fast.  I went into the settings and had to look through many areas to find what was draining the battery. (It even drained when off completely).  I turned off a few settings and now the drain is slower.  However, this HDX is also much slower in downloading books, etc.  My original Fire can download a book in seconds, whereas this one takes many many minutes.  I'm not sure why.  I have to say if I only had one Kindle I would keep my original Fire and skip the HDX.  I don't see many advantages to it other than the camera and definitely many disadvantages.  I gave it a 3 star rating simply because the Kindle is a great thing to have, but I would give the original Fire a 5.

Reviews.Title: Good replacement for original Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: NV Blonde Shopper
Reviews.Content: This is a replacement for the original Kindle Fire.  It is a little wider that the original and does not fit in my small hand as well as the old one.  The physical volume control buttons are better than the original on screen volume controls.  The slanted back cover is a little hard to get used to.  I really loved my original Kindle Fire and this is not so much better or different that I would not have spent the money to get a new one if the other had not died after only 2 years and I just spent $79 to get the Prime subscription.  I just don't see that much difference in the screen quality or battery life.  If I had not had the original Kindle Fire perhaps I would be more impressed with the HDX. If this is your first Kindle Fire I am sure you will be pleased.  I purchased a case that has a cover with an automatic sleep and on feature when the cover is closed and opened and I like that. However, it does not charge when the cover is closed for some reason which is kind of annoying.

Reviews.Title: A VERY nice choice in the 7" market. Better than my Samsung.
Reviews.Author: wizardshat
Reviews.Content: A great tablet. Awesome resolution! Sound is accurate and loud. This little thing is FAST!!!!! I got my girlfriend a Kindle HD for XMAS and wanted to try the next level up. I will be getting her one of these for this XMAS and giving the regular one to our daughter.**Update**I have the Fire TV and the game controller for it. I haven't yet tried, but they say the game controller can connect to this too. SWEET! But, I have sent video back and forth between the HDX and the Fire TV. That is a great feature. Instead of pausing the television when I head to the kitchen for a snack, I can send it to the HDX where it picks up seamlessly. Then I carry the tablet to the kitchen and get what I want and then head back to the living room and send the video back to the Fire TV. I know this may sound lazy, but this is truly a cool feature. Combine this with being able to download some videos to the tablet to watch offline and this has to be the best set up available. I admit that I am an Amazon superfan. They have really done their research and made quality products. I highly reccomend all of them.

Reviews.Title: great tablet
Reviews.Author: Loves to Read
Reviews.Content: This is a great tablet. It has alot of the capabilities of some of the other like iPad or the Samsung Galaxy. I'm able to watch movies- the color is amazing, I can surf, and get free e books from Amazon. The only downside is that either I can't personalize my homepage or I haven't figured out how yet. Easy to use. Great product for the price.

Reviews.Title: disappointed
Reviews.Author: Brady Baker
Reviews.Content: I was very disappointed in the fact that I purchased a kindle fire hdx for my newly retired mother to enjoy and it broke  while she was on vacation in florida. It was a Christmas  present .She called amazon and they tried to fix the issue and wasnt able so a new one was sent. She was told a new one would be sent along with a return shipping label. Well no label was sent so I had to find a friend with a printer, which was not easy. My only concern is sending the bad one back after so long. Thx for your concern.

Reviews.Title: KindleFire
Reviews.Author: Pamela Janus
Reviews.Content: So sorry, but my KindleFire lasted long enough to get two books and a CD and then just stopped working. I am having it sent back to you.It's a shame because I was so excited with my son's Christmas present to me.Regards,Pamela Janus

Reviews.Title: distraught
Reviews.Author: debbie bakker
Reviews.Content: My kindle just died. I bought it for a Christmas gift for myself and it won't turn on any more.

Reviews.Title: A very good device for reading & videos, but NOT an iPad replacement
Reviews.Author: Gadget Guy
Reviews.Content: The HDX has a beautiful display and very smooth touch-screen operation. As a device for browsing the web, viewing movies and, most especially, reading, it is the best device I've ever tried. It is not without its failings when compared to other tablets (or even the iPhone), but overall I like it. The review that follows is more of a semi-organized narrative vs a table of pros/cons or an organized feature list with scores.Rotation (for apps that support it) is really fast and seamless. The place where rotation doesn't do what I'd expect is email; more on that below.The response time when turned on is what you'd expect. It would be nice if it was easier to stop other apps from running; even iOS 6 has a straightforward way for this (much better in iOS 7). Amazon stuck with the slow & clunky Settings/Apps/Running method that has been in Android seemingly forever. Some apps get pretty unhappy with you if you force them to stop. You can reboot for a clean start, but that makes start-up pretty slow. A pity that while keeping this Android feature they disabled some other key features (see below for Apps issue).Books and even newspapers display their text and pictures beautifully. The paging is snappy unlike my older 2nd Gen Kindle, and for speech-enabled books, the speech synthesis system is decent. I LOVE the X-Ray feature. It is not perfect, but I assume it will just keep getting better.Silk is a decent web browser, but not as smooth as its name tries to imply. It is fast, but doesn't work with some important websites; and when it doesn't work it really doesn't work. Take Google Maps for instance. The display of Google Maps just plain sucks. No doubt about it. My iPhone handles Google Maps much better (and has a Google Maps app). No, I don't plan to take my Kindle on the road as a map device, but I would like to use it instead of my iPhone when a computer isn't handy; but that is not to be. To make things worse, there is no Google Maps app in Amazon's store. And to add insult to injury, you cannot install apps from Google Play unless you root your Kindle. That just plain sucks. This takes thousands of Android apps and puts them out of your reach. Amazon already has a "don't install from other app stores" switch there. When I turn that off, the Kindle HDX should just work with Google Play... I do not understand why Amazon made this choice and the Kindle HDX is poorer for it.I don't have many apps installed (some that I want to install I cannot -- see note above about Google Play). Some that I did install are ill-suited to my Kindle (e.g. Audubon Birds) as they have a fixed orientation and don't understand rotation. I'll probably stick to books and movies (and newspapers), which no doubt suits Amazon just fine.On the question of e-mail: the Kindle's email support looks pretty, but is pretty non-functional for me. I have an Exchange account plus some iMAP-only accounts that I setup. The Exchange account works really well, except for the Kindle's UI (see below) and some odd configuration things. For instance, no matter how many times I changed my notification sound, the HDX insisted on playing a different one. I even tried using the MAYDAY feature to see if the support gurus could help. I got my HDX on the first day they were available, so the support gurus will still learning the device and did not offer up anything I did not know. In the end I turned off notification and rely on my iPhone to alert me.The mail UI is disappointing in that when I rotate my HDX to landscape mode to gain reading space, the HDX instead insists on showing an Outlook-like 2 pane UI. I thought there was no way to change this, until another user (thanks, Judy) pointed out that a 3-dot menu shows up when a message is selected. That menu allows you to switch to fullscreen mode while viewing the message.WORST THING OF ALL with email: The HDX would randomly mark some unviewed messages as read. This took me many, many days to figure out, and caused me to miss some time-critical messages. How do I know it's the HDX? It started after I setup my iMAP accounts on the HDX; it stopped when I deleted them (another ding vs. other devices I've used: no way to disable the account just for testing -- you must delete it or use it).It is nice that installing my Exchange mailbox brought over my contacts & calendar, though I really don't need yet another device chiming to remind me of meetings. So I use this more as a quick check when reading so I don't need to get my iPhone out.The virtual keyboard is ok, but only just ok. It isn't smart about things like automatically engaging the shift key after punctuation or on a new line (I thought I disliked that about the iPhone at times, but the HDX made me realize how handy it is -- sad that my year-old iPhone has a better typing UI than my new HDX though). The spacing makes it easier to type on than a phone, but I miss the iPhone's features (perhaps just because I've become used to them). I do like the running display of word choices that show up as I type.A general configuration gripe: why is there only 1 sound type to be configured? There are notifications for: email, apps, calendar... why just one sound? And why don't changes to that take hold? Sigh, yes it is a smaller detail but one that impacts the "fit and finish" of the device. It's not like Amazon hasn't shipped out a tablet-ish device before, so this disappointed me.Movies -- now this is a REALLY nice feature. The speakers on the HDX (especially with the origami cover in place -- separate review coming on that) are just ok; I'd plug a nice headset in to listen. It is very cool that you can download prime movies onto the device and go on the road with those. What I do not understand is why the HDX has no way to SEARCH for downloadable prime movies. Instead, you need to browse, movie-by-movie, to find the ones that can be downloaded. C'mon, Amazon... really?? I haven't watched a movie on my HDX yet but will on a future road trip. I just hope the battery holds up.The UI for viewing photos is marginal; there is no good way to search for, sort or group photos. You just need to scroll through them and try to spot what you want. Worse, when you copy pictures across the USB interface (yay for a USB interface -- with the display, the only other technical advantage the HDX has), the picture's creation date is tossed. The HDX sets the creation date to the date the picture was copied; I can see NO advantage to anybody except for the careless programmer who didn't have to add that feature to his or her spec. Once you find the picture you want though, the display is what you'd expect from the HDX. Again, if I really want to find a particular picture quickly, I guess I'll just go to my iPhone. I am not even sure I'll keep moving pictures to my Kindle.Music: don't use it. My iPhone syncs with iTunes and I also have an iPod. Moving all of that to Amazon's cloud or my HDX would require conversion from Apple's format. Just not worth the time. Some of my music was purchased from Amazon, and those songs are available. But it is a small subset. Top it off with marginal speakers in my configuration and, well I just don't use it.I am yet to try Skype, but I suspect it would work very well.The HDX comes connected to Amazon's store. That makes it easy to buy books or movies. If I ever remember to carry my HDX into my basement to watch movies, it could be an easy way to select a For Rent movie when I want to watch it through my XBox. Too bad the swipe-to-TV feature doesn't include using the Amazon XBox app... then I'd always take my HDX downstairs with me!That leads to another oddity: for some Kindle management features you have to leave Amazon's store app and use Silk (or your laptop or iPhone) to go onto the web. Why is that? I can buy stuff from Amazon (including expensive, physical merchandise), but if I want to add an email address to my "approved for documents" list I need to go sign-on via Silk and browse around their website to find that feature? Doesn't make sense to me.Now the Mayday feature -- it is a really nice idea. I am fairly technical, and when I ask for help it is usually on some detail (like why won't my changes to the Notification sound stick?) that is not easy to find in the documentation.
